column4: hello there. I have a fresh install of kubuntu on a machine that I cannot get online. Where can I download binaries of ubuntu packages? For some reason I cannot find a place. The webside that seems to provide them most likely (as derived through its name) is packages.ubuntu.com, which is offline. Today is such a weird day..
check out aptoncd
ubottu, jtaji: thanks a lot guys

ubottu, jtaji: About aptoncd.. The only machine that is capable of connecting to the internet at the moment is a mac, with which I am here right now. So on a normal day packages.ubuntu.com would be my choice to download binary packages from the web, right?
yeah, I think so
hum, oh my
or run the aptoncd in a livecd (if you have a 2nd cd drive) or in a liveusb (if you have one)

Hm nice idea, I probably never would have had the idea by myself, to run a live cd on my fully working macbook :) But I think I will give it a try tomorrow, if I cannot fix wlan on the other machine by that time... Thanks again
Actually I just wanted to download wicd right now... creating a whole package cd for that one application will be my last choice^^
see what packages it depends on though
I found a ftp mirror where I can grab the packages... http://mirror.bauhuette.fh-aachen.de/ubuntu/pool/universe/
hmmm, where are you based?
ok, perfect
Depends: python, python-support (>= 0.7.1), python-gtk2, python-dbus, wpasupplicant, python-glade2, wireless-tools, dhcpd | dhcp3-client | pump, net-tools | ethtool, net-tools | iproute, adduser
you'll need these :) (the ones with | between them are optional, i.e. at least one of net-tools or ethtool_
These are some nice suggestions. I already toyed around with wpa_supplicant, that's why I was hoping that wicd does the trick instead. I'll have a look at all these applications.
I meant that those were the package requirements for wicd
so if you want to get the wicd package from your mirror, you'll need those installed before it will install itself
Ah ok thanks, even better to know
this is why we use apt! it sorts out dependency hell for you
remember, each of those might have dependencies themselves...

Yeah I know, actually I was using *bsd, gentoo already about five years ago and ubuntu in vmware from within os x. You know back then they either provided an iso image full of binaries or I would have a router that I could connect to without a problem. These days there is no binaries cd and I left my router in my old flat. Right now I am sharing internet with my neighbors who own the router and I bet the router is sp
